150.Description: All military or police moves that fall short of the actual use of force, not otherwise specified.

153.Usage Notes: Use this code when the government mobilizes police power to demonstrate strength, mostly as a scare tactic.
153.Name: Mobilize or increase police power
153.Example: The government of Sindh province has ordered patrols by police and paramilitary soldiers after violent protests by Muslim groups.
153.Description: Increase the number of military personnel and/or weapons.

1213.Usage Notes: Use this code when the source actor refuses to cooperate in extraditions or other matters pertaining to legal proceedings.
1213.Name: Reject judicial cooperation
1213.Example: Yugoslavia on Thursday flatly rejected an Australian ultimatum to handover a guard involved in a shooting in front of the Yugoslav consulate in Sydney.
1213.Description: Refuse to engage in or expand cooperation in judicial matters.

152.Usage Notes: Use this event form to code formal military orders to go on alert. The party against whom the military move is directed is the target actor.
152.Name: Increase military alert status
152.Example: Israeli troops remained on alert in the occupied West Bank today to forestall more violence after a week of unprecedented Palestinian civil unrest.
152.Description: Heighten military readiness and caution; be prepared to use force.

137.Usage Notes: Threats to imprison as well as to use force to clamp down on opposition activities are coded here. Note that even though it might involve use of violence by police or other security forces, repression of dissidents is different from use of military force against another armed group; threats to use military force or to engage in battle are coded under 138 instead.
137.Name: Threaten with repression
137.Example: Cairo’s security chief has warned that police will no longer tolerate rallies by the Kifaya (“Enough”) group.

103.Usage Notes: This category contains sub-forms for more detailed coding whenever possible. The source could be demanding aid for itself or on behalf of a third party; in either case, the actor who is expected to provide assistance should be coded as the target.
103.Name: Demand material aid, not specified below
103.Example: The Third World Water Forum concluded on Saturday that the US and other developed nations must allocate greater financial resources to help with the battle against the global water and sanitation crisis.
103.Description: Require, demand provision of material assistance not otherwise specified.

054.Usage Notes: This event form is typically, although not exclusively, a verbal act. Recognition of newly independent states, new governments that might have come to power through unconventional means, and initiation of diplomatic ties with an entity for the first time are all coded here.
054.Name: Grant diplomatic recognition
054.Example: Sri Lanka has established diplomatic ties with and opened an embassy in Tehran, the foreign ministry said on Wednesday.
054.Description: Grant diplomatic recognition, initiate diplomatic relations with a state or a government.

055.Usage Notes: Although this event form is typically a verbal act, it should also be used to code all nonverbal acts that express remorse
055.Name: Apologize
055.Example: Argentina has apologized to Brazil for one of its gunboats intercepting a Brazilian ship in the Beagle Channel, disputed by Argentina and Chile.
055.Description: Express regret or remorse for an action or situation

056.Usage Notes: Use this event form to code verbal and nonverbal gestures of forgiveness and explicitly conciliatory actions or announcements. Formal pardons and amnesties of arrested persons, as well as the release or exchange of prisoners, should be coded as CAMEO 0831 instead.
056.Name: Forgive
056.Example: A group of Yoruba leaders announced yesterday that they are willing to forgive President Olusegun Obasanjo and queue behind him for a second term.

057.Usage Notes: This category excludes promises to sign or ratify agreements and treaties. Events should be coded under this category only when agreements are reportedly finalized or signed. This event code is typically reciprocal. Even when the agreement in question implies a formal commitment to boost material cooperation, provide aid, or yield in some way, the event of signing the agreement or treaty is still coded here since signing of an agreement or treaty represents diplomatic cooperation but does not guarantee implementation— whatever its terms.
057.Name: Sign formal agreement
057.Example: Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi and Bulgarian President Todor Zhivkov today signed a treaty of friendship and cooperation, the BTA reported.
057.Description: Ratify, sign, finalize an agreement, treaty.

050.Usage Notes: This residual category is not coded except when the support in question cannot be further specified and codes 051-057 cannot be used.
050.Name: Engage in diplomatic cooperation, not specified below
050.Example: Czechoslovakia and Albania have upgraded their diplomatic ties back up to ambassadorial level after an 18-year break, the official CTK news agency said on Wednesday
050.Description: Initiate, resume, improve, or expand diplomatic, non-material cooperation or exchange not otherwise specified.

051.Usage Notes: This event form is typically, although not exclusively, a verbal act.
051.Name: Praise or endorse
051.Example: A top U.S. official today praised Haiti’s efforts to improve its record on human rights and said it was an important partner for the United States.
051.Description: Express support for, commend, approve policy, action, or actor

052.Usage Notes: This event form is a verbal act. Use this code only for political, diplomatic, and non-material defense; military cooperation or defense should be coded elsewhere
052.Name: Defend verbally
052.Example: The United States on Thursday defended the right of Soviet troops to fire protectively on militants in Azerbaijan and insisted unrest there reflected age-old ethnic tensions, not a fight for political independence
052.Description: Defend verbally, justify policy, action or actor

053.Usage Notes: This event form is typically, although not exclusively, a verbal act. Use this event form to code instances where one party (the source) solicits the support of third parties for another party (the target).
053.Name: Rally support on behalf of
053.Example: Arab League Secretary-General Chedli Klibi today urged the European Community to support the Palestinian Liberation Organization (PLO), which he said would create a favorable climate for peace talks.
053.Description: Call on other parties to support the target.

0343.Usage Notes: If it is clear from the lead that by promising to provide certain rights the source is in fact committing to yield, the event might be better coded under 035. Commitments to provide compensation for previously violated rights, for instance, are coded as 035.
0343.Name: Express intent to provide rights
0343.Example: Turkey will allow up to 13,000 Turkish Kurd refugees who have lived in Iraq for more than a decade to return home as part of a UN-brokered deal.
0343.Description: Offer, promise, agree to, or otherwise indicate willingness or commitment to provide social, political, economic, or other rights and freedoms

0342.Usage Notes: Use this code for commitments to bring policy change—political, economic, military, social, or otherwise. If the policy change in question clearly represents a form of yielding, the appropriate code under 035 should be used instead.
0342.Name: Express intent to change policy
0342.Example: Planning and Investment Minister Tran Xuan Gia said Vietnam is committed to opening up the economy but will not be rushed, in a rare interview late on Friday.
0342.Description: Offer, promise, agree to, or otherwise indicate willingness or commitment for policy change.

0341.Usage Notes: Commitments to resign or hand over power, as well to hold elections that might open the way for change in leadership, are coded here. Note that while commitments for other forms of yielding are coded under 035, commitments to give up power are coded here
0341.Name: Express intent to change leadership
0341.Example: Ousted President Askar Akayev has agreed to resign without returning to the Kyrgyzstan, the Parliament speaker said Saturday.
0341.Description: Offer, promise, agree to, or otherwise indicate willingness or commitment to change leadership or relinquish power

101.Usage Notes: Use the following sub-categories whenever possible. Demands for judicial cooperation, such as extradition of criminals, or compliance with requirements of an investigation are coded here.
101.Name: Demand material cooperation,
101.Example: French President Jacques Chirac issued a stern reminder Saturday to Iraq that it must cooperate fully with UN inspectors probing suspect sites for weapons of mass destruction.
101.Description: Require, demand that target engages in some form of material exchange.

1424.Usage Notes: Note the difference between institutional/constitutional changes and policy reforms. Hunger strikes that call for independence or autonomy essentially demand major changes to the whole system and are hence coded here
1424.Name: Conduct hunger strike for change in institutions, regime
1424.Example: A group of Chenchen refugees are continuing a hunger strike in protest of the Russian government’s refusal to accept the independence of Chechnya.
1424.Description: Refuse to eat until demands for major institutional, constitutional, or regime change.

0344.Usage Notes: Note the difference between institutional/regime changes and policy reforms.
0344.Name: Express intent to change institutions, regime
0344.Example: Serbian President Vojislav Kostunica promised to democratize Serbia and establish the rule of law as he succeeded Milosevic.
0344.Description: Offer, promise, agree to, or otherwise indicate willingness or commitment to make fundamental political changes, such as moving from one type of political system to another and reforming political institutions or key laws. Usage Notes Note the difference between institutional/regime changes and policy reforms

0862.Usage Notes: Code here reported deployment or arrival of inspectors; mere promises or agreements to accept their deployment should be coded as 0355 instead. The target for an 085 event should be the inspectors or the country/agency providing them. This event form is typically accompanied by code under category 09.
0862.Name: Receive inspectors
0862.Example: The IAEA has dispatched inspectors to Esfahan Uranium Conversion Facilities (UCF) in central Iran to monitor resumption of peaceful nuclear work at the plant.
0862.Description: Allow, receive inspectors in territories controlled by the source actor.

175.Usage Notes: Note the difference between repression of dissidents and military engagements.
175.Name: Use repression
175.Example: Liberian riot police used tear gas to disperse demonstrators protesting election results in Monrovia.
175.Description: Actively repress collective actions of dissent by forcing subjugation through crowd control tactics, arrests, etc.

071.Usage Notes: The lead must report the delivery of such aid; promises to provide aid should be coded under 033 instead. Debt relief should also be coded as 071.
071.Name: Provide economic aid
071.Example: The European Community on Monday gave the Ivory Coast 5.1 million dollars of aid for agricultural development projects
071.Description: Extend, provide monetary aid and financial guarantees, grants, gifts and credit.

0863.Usage Notes: Mere promises to allow such access should be coded as 0355. Note that this event form is accompanied by the linked event ‘Provide humanitarian aid’ (073) if the target is the humanitarian agency; in some cases the target would be the particular area that is given access
0863.Name: Allow for humanitarian access
0863.Example: Humanitarian access for the Darfur region has improved significantly since September as the Khartoum government tried to secure international favor.
0863.Description: Allow access to, receive humanitarian agencies in territories controlled by the source actor.

182.Usage Notes: This event form category contains sub-forms for more detailed coding whenever possible. Beatings are coded here.
182.Name: Physically assault, not specified below
182.Example: Israeli soldiers routinely beat up Palestinian detainees on the occupied West Bank with the knowledge of senior officers, a court martial was told today.
182.Description: Attack physical well-being of individuals without the use of weaponry, not otherwise specified.

183.Usage Notes: Aerial bombings that involve the use of aircrafts are coded as 195 instead.
183.Name: Conduct suicide, car, or other non-military bombing, not specified below
183.Example: Irish nationalist guerrillas wounded two British soldiers in a bomb attack on Thursday, police said.
183.Description: Use improvised explosives or makeshift bombs not otherwise specified.

180.Usage Notes: Use this event form to code use of forms of force and violence that do not require high levels of organization typical of state-military establishments. Terrorist attacks, if not further specified, should be coded here. Use this default code also for use of knives, rocks and other such unsophisticated weapons. This residual category is not coded except when distinctions among codes 181-186 cannot be made.
180.Name: Use unconventional violence, not specified below
180.Example: A temporary camp for Congolese refugees was attacked by Burundian militiamen armed with machetes, killing at least 156 people, the UN refugee agency reported.
180.Description: Use of unconventional forms of violence which do not require high levels of organization or conventional weaponry, not otherwise specified.

181.Name: Abduct, hijack, take hostage
181.Example: Afghan rebels have kidnapped up to 16 Soviet civilian advisers from a town bazaar and exploded a series of bombs in the capital Kabul, western diplomatic sources in neighboring Pakistan said today.
181.Description: Kidnap, take hostage, hijack, or forcibly seize control of an aircraft, car, bus, ship, etc.

186.Usage Notes: Use this event form to code targeted killings and assassinations of politically influential elites or leaders.
186.Name: Assassinate
186.Example: Hezbollah guerrillas killed the deputy chief of Israel’s militia ally in southern Lebanon Sunday sources on both sides said.
186.Description: Kill politically significant and influential persons.

104.Usage Notes: This event form refers to verbal and non-threatening appeals. Demands that take the form of demonstrations, protests, etc. are coded under category 14 instead. Source actors can be local citizens as well as international actors; they could be making the appeal on their own behalf or on behalf of others. Note that when the requested reform clearly constitutes some form of concession or yielding by the target, such as the easing of administrative sanctions, a more appropriate “Demand” code might be found under 105.
104.Name: Demand political reform, not specified below
104.Example: At the end of a seminar on reform, around 100 Arab intellectuals and activists published a declaration demanding wide-ranging political changes in the Arab world.
104.Description: Require, demand political change not otherwise specified

184.Name: Use as human shield
184.Example: The Sri Lankan army has been holding thousands of Tamil civilian refugees as human shields in the battle zones of the southern sector of the Jaffna peninsula, according to a press release by the Liberation Tigers.
184.Description: Use civilians as buffer on the front lines or in other dangerous environments.

185.Usage Notes: Use this code only when an assassination attempt or targeted killing is foiled; when assassinations are successfully carried out, 186 is used instead. This distinction is made because consequences of these two types of events could be significantly different. The source of this event would ideally be the assailant; however, in many cases this information will not be available and the location of the attack would be coded as the source instead.
185.Name: Attempt to assassinate
185.Example: An attempt to assassinate deputy governor of the Tyumen region, Oleg Chemezov, was thwarted in Khanty-Mansiysk (Siberia), the city’s police reported.
185.Description: Attempt but fail to kill politically significant and influential persons

1032.Usage Notes: Note that demands for military security and deployment of peacekeepers are coded as 1034 instead.
1032.Name: Demand military aid
1032.Description: Require, demand provision of military assistance.

1033.Usage Notes: Demands by refugees to be let into the territories of other countries (which should be coded as targets) and asylum demands all fit here. These are not necessarily verbal acts; refugees could be actively seeking shelter or refuge in target countries or regions
1033.Name: Demand humanitarian aid
1033.Example: Some 800,000 Iraqi Kurds sought refuge in Germany last month.
1033.Description: Require, demand provision of humanitarian aid

0861.Usage Notes: Code here reported deployment of peacekeeping forces (with location of deployment as the source); mere promises or agreements by fighting parties or a country to accept deployment of peacekeeping forces in its territories should be coded as 0355, and commitments to provide peacekeepers should be coded as 0334. The target for an 084 event should be the actor providing the peacekeepers. Note that this event form is accompanied by the linked event ‘Provide military protection or peacekeeping’ (074).
0861.Name: Receive deployment of peacekeepers
0861.Example: A first patch of Bangladeshi peacekeeping troops arrived in Sierra Leone Tuesday, joining 12 unarmed military observers as the first element of an 800-strong Bangladeshi contingent due here, U.N. officials said.
0861.Description: Allow, receive peacekeeping forces in territories controlled by the source.

1034.Usage Notes: The source that demands peacekeepers could demand that for itself or on behalf of another party.
1034.Name: Demand military protection or peacekeeping
1034.Example: Ethnic Albanians in south Serbia are demanding a U.N. military presence to protect them against a heavily armed ruling Serb minority and prevent a Bosnia-style civil war, but some foreign monitors are skeptical.
1034.Description: Require, demand that the target provides military protection or peacekeeping forces.

061.Usage Notes: Trade relations and other economic exchanges that are reciprocal in nature— event if the particular event in question cannot be coded as reciprocal— should be coded here. Unilateral and potentially altruistic provisions of economic aid should be coded as 071 instead.
061.Name: Cooperate economically
061.Example: European foreign direct investment flows in Latin America and the Caribbean rose more than eightfold during the second half of the 1990s compared with the first half of that decade, according to a study presented in Paris by the Inter-American Development Bank.
061.Description: Initiate, resume, improve, or expand economic exchange or cooperation.

060.Usage Notes: This residual category is not coded except when distinctions among codes 061-064 cannot be made
060.Name: Engage in material cooperation, not specified below
060.Example: Taliban ruled Afghanistan has been sharing expertise with the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam according to a special report submitted to the Canadian Security Intelligence Service
060.Description: Initiate, resume, improve, or expand material cooperation or exchange, not otherwise specified.

063.Usage Notes: This code represents cooperation on judicial matters, such as extraditions and war crimes.
063.Name: Engage in judicial cooperation
063.Example: Zambia extradited suspected British militant Haroon Rashid Aswad to Britain on Sunday, a senior Zambian government official said.
063.Description: Initiate, resume, improve, or expand judicial cooperation.

0241.Usage Notes: This event form refers to verbal and non-threatening appeals. More forceful “demands” for leadership change are coded as 1041; demonstrations, protests, etc. demanding change in leadership/power are coded under category 14. Note that even though calls for the target to resign or relinquish power are forms of yielding, they are still coded here. Also code appeals for elections here.
0241.Name: Appeal for leadership change
0241.Example: Members of parliament from Kenya’s Liberal Democratic Party called on Energy Minister Kiraitu Murungi to resign in the wake of new evidence over the $7 billion scandals.
0241.Description: Make an appeal for, request, or suggest change in leadership or power.

122.Usage Notes: Use this event form to code refusals to provide material assistance. Use sub-categories whenever possible.
122.Name: Reject request or demand for material aid, not specified below
122.Description: Refuse to extend material aid not otherwise specified.

064.Usage Notes: Voluntary exchanges or sharing of intelligence and other significant information should be coded here
064.Name: Share intelligence or information
064.Example: Israeli intelligence officials have shared evidence with the U.S. about contacts between al Qaeda and senior members of Saddam Hussein’s Ba’ath Party, according to governmental officials.
064.Description: Provide, share, or exchange intelligence or information

0244.Usage Notes: This event form refers to verbal and non-threatening appeals. More forceful “demands” for institutional change are coded as 1044; demonstrations, protests, etc. demanding such change are coded under category 14. Institutional change is different from policy change in that the former directly alters the rules of the game. Requests for fundamental changes in the political system (e.g. democratization) as well as for more limited institutional changes (e.g. changing electoral law) are coded here.
0244.Name: Appeal for change in institutions, regime
0244.Example: President Emile Lahoud has pushed the Lebanese Parliament for a new election law two days before he is to call parliamentary elections.
0244.Description: Make an appeal for, request, or suggest major institutional, constitutional, or regime change.

120.Usage Notes: This residual category is not coded except when distinctions among codes 121-127 cannot be made. All rejections coded under this category should imply refusals to cooperate or yield in some way.
120.Name: Reject, not specified below
120.Example: The Palestinians reject proposed Israeli changes to the Wye River land-forsecurity deal, chief Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erakat said.
120.Description: All rejections and refusals not otherwise specified.

191.Usage Notes: Note that this event form is different from code 144 (‘Obstruct physically’), which refers to civilian protest activities that seek to disrupt routine and normal proceedings
191.Name: Impose blockade, restrict movement
191.Example: Israel Friday reimposed blockades in the West Bank following the shooting deaths of two Israelis a day earlier, a military spokesman announced.
191.Description: Prevent entry into and/or exit from a territory using armed forces

1211.Usage Notes: Use this code for rejections of mutual economic exchange, such as trade and investment; rejection to provide financial aid (or cancel debt) is coded as 1221 instead.
1211.Name: Reject economic cooperation
1211.Example: Bangladesh has once again outright rejected an Indian proposal for signing Free Trade Agreement (FTA) with her, urging the counterpart to sign the proposed South Asia Free Trade Agreement (SAFTA) instead.
1211.Description: Refuse to engage in or expand economic ties.

202.Usage Notes: s Politically motivated mass killings and genocides are coded here, relying primarily on the specific terminology used by reporters to identify an event that involves “mass” killings.
202.Name: Engage in mass killings
202.Example: Sudan’s government is responsible for mass killings and other atrocities in the Darfur region, according to a United Nations report.
202.Description: Kill a substantial number of people, typically with the intention of ridding a territory of a particular group of people.

1434.Usage Notes: Note the difference between institutional/constitutional changes and policy reforms. Strikes that call for independence or autonomy essentially demand major changes to the whole system and are hence coded here.
1434.Name: Conduct strike or boycott for change in institutions, regime
1434.Description: Refuse to work or cooperate until demands for major institutional, constitutional, or regime change.

190.Usage Notes: This residual category is not coded except when distinctions among codes 191-196 cannot be made. In addition to unspecified acts of fighting, “killings” of any kind when the weapons used are not specified should also be coded here. When news leads refer to acts of killing that take place during an attack or some form of military engagement as “murders”, those should still be coded here. However, murders in general—as criminal acts with no political connotations—are not coded under the CAMEO framework. The first example below illustrates how one can differentiate between these two different uses of the verb “murder”.
190.Name: Use conventional military force, not specified below
190.Example: One Serb policeman was murdered in an attack on a police patrol by Kosovo Albanians near the border with Kosovo, state agency Tanjug reported Sunday.
190.Description: All uses of conventional force and acts of war typically by organized armed groups not otherwise specified.

1663.Usage Notes: Use this event form to code both expulsions by host countries and withdrawals by providers of humanitarian aid. When aid is simply reduced or halted but the expulsion or withdrawal of the provider is not mentioned, use 1623 instead.
1663.Name: Expel or withdraw aid agencies
1663.Example: Jakarta forced the UN refugee agency, UNHCR, out of the country following the relief operation, although it had more than £12m of unspent donations.
1663.Description: n Terminate the presence of aid agencies or other non-governmental organizations helping civilians

1385.Usage Notes: This event form is typically a verbal act. Use this code for threats to carry out actions best represented in cue category 20.
1385.Name: Threaten unconventional mass violence
1385.Example: A terror group based in Trinidad claims to be manufacturing chemical and biological weapons to use against the United States and Britain, according to a media report Sunday.
1385.Description: Threaten to use force potentially affecting large masses of people, including the use of weapons of mass destruction (nuclear or chemical-biologicalradiological attacks), mass expulsions or killings, as well as ethnic cleansing.

164.Usage Notes: Use this event form to code failed negotiations and walk-outs, as well as other disruptions of planned negotiations. Note that the termination can be either unilateral or bi/multi-lateral.
164.Name: Halt negotiations
164.Example: Palestinians and Israelis failed to reach agreement on the fate of Palestinian offices in east Jerusalem Sunday, despite hours of tense negotiations, sources on both sides reported.

1432.Usage Notes: Use this code when protesters demand specific policy changes or unspecified political reforms.
1432.Name: Conduct strike or boycott for policy change
1432.Example: Some 500,000 workers affiliated with the Serbian Workers’ Union (SSS) stopped work on the first day of an open-ended strike on Monday over a controversial employment bill signed in by Serbian Labour Minister Dragan Milovanovic.
1432.Description: Refuse to work or cooperate until demands for policy reform are met.

166.Usage Notes: Use this category to code both expulsions by host authorities and withdrawals by guest groups or organizations. Note that expulsions or deportations of individuals—typically a legal matter—are coded as 174 instead. Mass expulsions of peoples are coded as 201. Withdrawal of hostile military forces constitutes a form of yielding and is thus coded as 089. When diplomats are withdrawn or expelled, use 161.
166.Name: Expel or withdraw, not specified below
166.Description: Terminate the presence of groups or organizations not otherwise specified

160.Usage Notes: This residual category is not coded except when distinctions among codes 161-166 cannot be made.
160.Name: Reduce relations, not specified below
160.Example: Italy announced a suspension of air links with Yugoslavia on Wednesday, one day after a Yugoslav army jet shot down a helicopter carrying EC truce monitors.
160.Description: All reductions in normal, routine, or cooperative relations not otherwise specified.

161.Usage Notes: Cancellation of meetings, withdrawal, or expulsion of diplomats and termination of other diplomatic activities (excluding negotiations and mediations which are coded as 163 and 165 respectively) should be coded here.
161.Name: Reduce or break diplomatic relations
161.Example: A French minister has cancelled a planned visit to Haiti after a state of siege was declared in the one-time French colony, the Foreign Affairs Ministry said on Sunday.
161.Description: Curtail, decrease, break, or terminate diplomatic exchange

0831.Usage Notes: Use this code when source surrenders power after being challenged through legitimate institutional channels (e.g. elections) or other coercive strategies (e.g. military coups). The target can either be the challenger(s) or the country as a whole.
0831.Name: Accede to demands for change in leadership
0831.Example: Tuesday the Serbian parliament approved a “special law” recognizing victories by Zoran Djindjic’s opposition coalition in November 17 municipal elections in 14 of the 18 most important Serbian cities, including Belgrade.

1433.Usage Notes: Use this code for strikes or boycotts that demand new rights or protest the violation of existing ones.
1433.Name: Conduct strike or boycott for rights
1433.Example: Seven opposition parties in Nepal have organized a general strike that shut down Khatmandu in protest of last week’s arrest of a number of activists.
1433.Description: Refuse to work or cooperate until demands for political, social, economic, or other rights are met.

1623.Name: Reduce or stop humanitarian assistance
1623.Example: The United Nations on Tuesday reduced food supplies to the biggest Cambodian refugee camp in Thailand because rice was being diverted to outside users, relief officials said.
1623.Description: Decrease or terminate provision of humanitarian aid

1622.Name: Reduce or stop military assistance
1622.Example: The United States suspended part of a military aid program for Bosnia aimed at bringing Bosnian Croat and Moslem armed forces together as a unified identity, the New York Times reported on Friday.
1622.Description: Decrease or terminate provision of military aid

1621.Name: Reduce or stop economic assistance
1621.Example: Japan said on Tuesday it had halted economic aid to Yugoslavia in line with Western efforts to end the fighting there.
1621.Description: Decrease or terminate provision of economic aid.

1031.Usage Notes: This event form is typically, although not exclusively, a verbal act. Demands for loans or debt relief are also coded here. Demands for reciprocal economic exchange, such as trade, should be coded as 1011 instead.
1031.Name: Demand economic aid
1031.Example: According to reports the UK is pushing hard for the US support its debt relief plan to tackle poverty in Africa.
1031.Description: Require, demand provision of economic assistance.

121.Usage Notes: This category contains sub-forms for more detailed coding whenever possible. Refusals to provide unilateral material assistance—not mutual exchange— are coded as 122 instead. Note the difference between refusing to establish or expand material cooperation and reducing or eliminating existing ties (category 16).
121.Name: Reject material cooperation, not specified below
121.Example: Yemen has rejected a U.S. request to interrogate detainees held after the escape of 23 al-Qaida prisoners, a security official said Tuesday.
121.Description: Refuse to engage in or expand material exchange.

114.Name: Complain officially
114.Example: Yugoslavia lodged an official protest with Albania today, charging its neighbor with supporting dissidents here in what is said was tantamount to inciting revolution.
114.Description: Written and institutionalized protests, appeals, and all petition drives and recalls.

1044.Usage Notes: This event form refers to verbal and non-threatening appeals. Demands that take the form of demonstrations, protests, etc. are coded under category 14 instead. Institutional change is different from policy change in that the former directly alters the rules of the game. Demands for fundamental changes in the political system (e.g. democratization) as well as more limited institutional changes (e.g. changing electoral law) are coded here.
1044.Name: Demand change in institutions, regime
1044.Example: Rwandan rebels announced that President Kagame and his Rwandan Patriotic Front must agree to major constitutional changes before they demobilize.
1044.Description: Require, demand major institutional, constitutional, or regime change.

1454.Usage Notes: Note the difference between institutional/constitutional changes and policy reforms. Riots that call for independence or autonomy essentially demand major changes to the whole system and are hence coded here.
1454.Name: Engage in violent protest to demand change in institutions, regime
1454.Example: Prisoners rioted at a jail in East Timor’s capital Dili on Monday joining thousands of demonstrators in demanding a referendum on independence from Indonesian rule, locals said.
1454.Description: Protest forcefully, in a potentially destructive manner, to demand major institutional, constitutional, or regime change.

116.Usage Notes: Source must be the court in question, which could be domestic or international, and target must be the defendant. This event form refers typically to rulings against non-individuals, where imprisonment is not an issue. When individuals are found guilty and are therefore detained, use 173 instead
116.Name: Find guilty or liable (legally)
116.Example: A European court convicted Turkey of ”inhuman acts” Thursday for destroying the home of a Kurdish citizen in the country’s southeast.
116.Description: Find guilty or liable at a court of law

1451.Usage Notes: Target should be the actor who is expected to relinquish power. Riots that demand new elections should also be coded here.
1451.Name: Engage in violent protest for leadership change
1451.Example: Egyptian demonstrators rioted following a peaceful demonstration calling for the immediate removal of President Hosni Mubarak from office.
1451.Description: Protest forcefully, in a potentially destructive manner, to demand leadership change.

1452.Usage Notes: Use this code when protesters demand specific policy changes or unspecified political reforms.
1452.Name: Engage in violent protest to demand policy change
1452.Example: Palestinian riots against Israeli military policies are still continuing with no end in sight.
1452.Description: Protest forcefully, in a potentially destructive manner, to demand policy reform.

1453.Usage Notes: Use this code for riots that demand new rights or protest the violation of existing ones.
1453.Name: Engage in violent protest to demand rights
1453.Example: Palestinian youths resorted to throwing stones during demonstrations against the alleged human rights violations by the Israeli military, officials said on Thursday.
1453.Description: Protest forcefully, in a potentially destructive manner, to demand political, social, economic, or other rights.

204.Name: Use weapons of mass destruction, not specified below
204.Description: n Attack with unconventional weapons that are meant to cause massive destruction and casualties.

0242.Usage Notes: This event form refers to verbal and non-threatening appeals. More forceful “demands” for policy change are coded as 1042; demonstrations, protests, etc. demanding change in leadership/power are coded under category 14. Just like the source actor, the policy in question can also be domestic or international in nature. If it is clear from the lead that by requesting certain policy changes the source is in fact appealing to the target to yield or concede, the event might be better coded under 035.
0242.Name: Appeal for policy change
0242.Example: U.S. President George W. Bush said Friday that he will tell Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi that Japan needs to enact significant economic reforms.
0242.Description: Make an appeal for, request, or suggest change in any particular policy.

074.Usage Notes: Code here reported deployment of forces; verbal promises and commitments to provide peacekeepers should be coded as 034. Note that this event form is accompanied by the linked event ’Receive deployment of peacekeepers’ (084)
074.Name: Provide military protection or peacekeeping
074.Example: The first deployment of NATO peacekeeping troops have arrived in Bosnia, Defense Secretary William Perry said.
074.Description: Provide peacekeepers or other military forces for protection, extend or expand their mandates.

075.Usage Notes: Asylum is typically granted by states to persons in its territories (territorial asylum) and it constitutes a legal protection awarded to those persons against other states. Diplomatic asylum, protection typically accorded on the premises of an embassy, can also be granted and is similarly coded here. Not that ‘Grant asylum’ refers to a specific legal event type; informal provisions of shelter or opening of borders to masses of refugees should be coded as ‘Provide humanitarian aid’ (073) instead.
075.Name: Grant asylum
075.Example: Peru has granted diplomatic asylum to five Panamanian army officers holed up in a diplomatic residence since last month’s U.S. invasion, the Peruvian embassy said on Tuesday.

072.Usage Notes: The lead must report the delivery of such aid; promises to provide aid should be coded under category 033 instead.
072.Name: Provide military aid
072.Example: The United States continued to send arms to Pakistan last year, a State Department Spokesman said Wednesday.
072.Description: Extend, provide military and police assistance including arms and personnel

073.Usage Notes: This code refers to events such as provisions of shelter, food, medicine, and evacuation of victims. The lead must report the delivery of such aid; promises to provide aid should be coded under category 033. Note that provisions of peacekeeping or other military forces are coded as 074 instead.
073.Name: Provide humanitarian aid
073.Example: Swiss doctors handed over 700 kg of medicine to the Red Crescent in Bam, Iran, according to the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation.
073.Description: Extend, provide humanitarian aid, mainly in the form of emergency assistance.

070.Usage Notes: This residual category is not coded except when distinctions among codes 071-075 cannot be made. In order to be coded under this category, the leads must report the delivery of aids; promises to provide aid should be coded under category 033 instead.
070.Name: Provide aid,
070.Example: Doctors from two American aid groups donated and personally delivered $50,000 worth of goods to Baghdad University Medical School, risking as much as 12 years in prison and $500,000 in fines.
070.Description: All provisions, extension of material aid,

0243.Usage Notes: This event form refers to verbal and non-threatening appeals. More forceful “demands” for rights are coded as 1043; demonstrations, protests, etc. demanding certain rights are coded under category 14. If it is clear from the lead that by requesting certain rights the source is in fact appealing to the target to yield or concede, the event might be better coded under 025. Appeals for provision of compensation for previously violated rights, for instance, are coded as 025.
0243.Name: Appeal for rights
0243.Example: The UN urged the Maoists rebels in Nepal to honor human rights, according to the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights (UNHCR).
0243.Description: Make an appeal for, request, or suggest provision or expansion of social, political, or other rights.

0255.Usage Notes: Requests for adversaries to allow mediation are coded as 028 instead.
0255.Name: Appeal to allow international involvement (non-mediation)
0255.Example: An international aid agency appealed to the Sudanese government on Friday to urgently reconsider its ban on relief flights to southern Sudan.
0255.Description: Make an appeal for, request, or suggest that target allows the entry of international actors, such as observers, humanitarian agencies, and peacekeeping forces

0254.Usage Notes: Use this code only for economic sanctions, boycotts, or embargoes.
0254.Name: Appeal for easing of economic sanctions, boycott, or embargo
0254.Example: Iraq on Saturday appealed to the U.N. to bring an end to their trade embargo, which it said is causing huge shortages of medicine and food.
0254.Description: Make an appeal for, request, or suggest that target stops or eases economic sanctions, boycott, or embargo.

0256.Usage Notes: Use this code for appeals for ceasefires, military withdrawals, and demobilization.
0256.Name: Appeal for target to de-escalation of military engagement
0256.Example: The presidents of Iraq and Egypt called on Tuesday for the withdrawal of Syrian and other foreign forces from Lebanon to end 14 years of civil war there.
0256.Description: Make an appeal for, request, or suggest that target stops fighting or takes measures to ease military conflict or tension.

0251.Usage Notes: Use this code when a government is requested to undertake some political changes that clearly constitute some form of concession or yielding, such as relaxing or removing bans or other restrictions that are already in place.
0251.Name: Appeal for easing of administrative sanction
0251.Example: Dozens of journalists at Sudan’s most respected daily newspaper appealed to the Sudanese government on Wednesday to let them resume publishing and compensate them for lost wages.
0251.Description: Make an appeal for, request, or suggest that target relaxes administrative restrictions.

1661.Usage Notes: Use this event form to code both expulsions of peacekeeping forces by host countries and voluntary withdrawals by actors providing the peacekeeping forces. Note that while the host country should be coded as the source actor when coding an expulsion of peacekeeping forces, the provider of the forces becomes the source when coding withdrawals.
1661.Name: Expel or withdraw peacekeepers
1661.Example: Eighty UN peacekeepers were shipped out of the eastern Bosnian enclave of Gorazde Friday, leaving just 100 UN troops to follow them out later this month.
1661.Description: Terminate the deployment or presence of peacekeeping forces.

0253.Usage Notes: Use this code for requests for the target to release prisoners, hostages, and any confiscated property.
0253.Name: Appeal for release of persons or property
0253.Example: The United States called on Israel to move forward with its “courageous and historic” disengagement plan as fast as possible.
0253.Description: Make an appeal for, request, or suggest that target releases persons or property

0252.Usage Notes: Use this code for requests for the target to stop engaging in protests, demonstrations, strikes, etc.
0252.Name: Appeal for easing of political dissent
0252.Example: Islamic fundamentalist leaders appealed to their Muslim followers for an end to anti-government agitation, authorities said Monday.
0252.Description: Make an appeal for, request, or suggest that target stops political protest activities.

062.Usage Notes: Military exchanges such as joint military games and maneuvers should be coded here. Unilateral and potentially altruistic provisions of aid should be coded under ‘Provide Aid’ (07) instead.
062.Name: Cooperate militarily
062.Example: French and Egyptian warships on Monday launched 10 days of war games in the Mediterranean Sea, expected to be joined later by Italian and German vessels, the French embassy said Monday.
062.Description: Initiate, resume, improve, or expand military exchange or cooperation.

100.Usage Notes: This residual category is not coded except when distinctions among codes 101-108 cannot be made. Note that demands are stronger or more forceful and potentially carry more serious repercussions—although not as much as threats—than simple appeals. We rely primarily on the language used by reporters to make this distinction. All demands are verbal acts.
100.Name: Demand, not specified below
100.Example: Poland’s parliament has demanded an immediate admission by Moscow that Soviet NKVD security forces murdered more than 15,000 captive Polish of- ficers during World War Two.
100.Description: All demands and orders not otherwise specified.

1721.Usage Notes: Restrictions on media and activities of political dissent are coded here. Note that if the event is about the actual enforcement of such restrictions through repressive tactics, such as imprisonments and dispersion of demonstrations, 175 should be used instead.
1721.Name: Impose restrictions on political freedoms
1721.Example: The British government on Monday outlawed the largest Protestant extremist organization in Northern Ireland because of what it called its direct involvement in killing in the strife-torn province
1721.Description: Violate or impose limitations on fundamental political rights such as freedoms of speech, expression, and assembly

1051.Usage Notes: Use this code when a government is pushed to undertake some political changes that clearly constitute some form of concession or yielding, such as relaxing or removing bans, curfews, or other restrictions that are already in place. Demands that take the form of demonstrations, protests, etc. are coded under category 14 instead.
1051.Name: Demand easing of administrative sanction
1051.Example: Human rights organization Amnesty International demanded that the Sudanese government end curbs on press freedom.
1051.Description: Require, demand that target relaxes administrative restrictions

1052.Usage Notes: Use this code for demands that the target stop engaging in protests, demonstrations, strikes, etc. Note that this code refers exclusively to verbal demands; if the source actively seeks to stop activities through repressive measures, 175 is used instead.
1052.Name: Demand easing of political dissent
1052.Example: Iranian authorities have been pressuring workers of the United Bus Company of Tehran (Sharekat-e Vahed) to cancel the strike they have been planning for better pay and working conditions.
1052.Description: Require, demand that target stops political protest activities.

1053.Usage Notes: Use this code for demands that the target release prisoners, hostages, and any confiscated property
1053.Name: Demand release of persons or property
1053.Example: Russia said on Tuesday that Sudan must return a Mi-26 helicopter that was captured by the Sudanese authorities last week.
1053.Description: Require, demand that target releases persons or property.

1054.Usage Notes: Use this code only for economic sanctions, boycotts, or embargoes
1054.Name: Demand easing of economic sanctions, boycott, or embargo
1054.Example: The 106th Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference stressed the obligation of the international community to take immediate action to lift embargoes and other sanctions which have negatively affected children in different parts of the world.
1054.Description: Require, demand that target lifts or eases economic sanctions, boycott, or embargo.

1055.Usage Notes: Demands for adversaries to allow mediation are coded as 108 instead.
1055.Name: Demand to allow international involvement (non-mediation)
1055.Example: Kenzo Oshima, the United Nations Emergency Relief Coordinator, demanded parties to the conflict in Iraq to allow humanitarian workers the freedom of movement necessary for discharging their mandate.
1055.Description: Require, demand that target allow access to international actors, such as observers, humanitarian agencies, and peacekeeping forces

1056.Usage Notes: Use this code for demands for ceasefires, military withdrawals, and demobilization.
1056.Name: Demand de-escalation of military engagement
1056.Example: Washington along with its allies demanded that Hamas renounce its armed struggle against Israel.
1056.Description: Require, demand that target stops fighting or takes measures to ease military conflict or tension.

0814.Name: Ease state of emergency or martial law
0814.Example: Yugoslavia eased emergency measures on Wednesday in Kosovo province, the scene of ethnic violence last March, as authorities in Croatia cracked down on Serbian nationalists.
0814.Description: Relax or remove emergency regulations that suspend certain given rights, or relax or remove temporary rule by military authorities.

0813.Name: Ease curfew
0813.Example: Yugoslavia lifted a night curfew in Kosovo where 28 people have been killed in ethnic riots this year and the province was reported quiet on Sunday.
0813.Description: Relax or remove regulations that require people to be off the streets at a given hour.

0812.Name: Ease ban on political parties or politicians
0812.Example: The Ivory Coast’s Supreme Court decided to allow candidate Alassane Ouattara to participate in the country’s upcoming elections.
0812.Description: Relax or remove administrative restrictions on the establishment or activities of political parties or certain politicians.

0811.Name: Ease restrictions on political freedoms
0811.Example: The Latvian Constitutional Court cancelled restrictions on the use of the Russian language on national radio and television.
0811.Description: Relax or remove administrative restrictions on fundamental political freedoms such as freedoms of speech, expression, and assembly

1242.Name: Refuse to ease popular dissent
1242.Example: Around 1,800 of 2,200 Serbian teachers will not end their strike unless their demands for wage increases are met by textcolorblueBelgrade, a union official announced after three weeks of striking.
1242.Description: Reject requests, refuse, or decline to reduce or stop political protest activi- ties, such as demonstrations and rallies.

1443.Usage Notes: Use this code for obstructions that demand new rights or protest the violation of existing ones
1443.Name: Obstruct passage to demand rights
1443.Example: Young Algerians blocked roads leading to the city centre on Sunday to press their demands for greater freedom and opportunities from President Boute- flika’s government.
1443.Description: Obstruct passage, block entry/exit to demand political, social, economic, or other rights.

1442.Usage Notes: Use this code when protesters demand specific policy changes or unspecified political reforms
1442.Name: Obstruct passage to demand policy change
1442.Example: Demonstrators in Baghdad blocked a road to show their disapproval for the United States’ military policies, a newspaper reported Tuesday.
1442.Description: Obstruct passage, block entry/exit to demand policy reform.

1441.Usage Notes: Target should be the actor who is expected to relinquish power. Obstructions that demand new elections should also be coded here.
1441.Name: Obstruct passage to demand leadership change
1441.Example: About 200 supporters of former President Ahmed Ben Bella blocked roads in the capital city of Algiers demanding that he be reinstated as leader of the Algerian government.
1441.Description: Obstruct passage, block entry/exit to demand leadership change.

1244.Usage Notes: Use this code only for economic sanctions, boycotts, or embargoes.
1244.Name: Refuse to ease economic sanctions, boycott, or embargo
1244.Example: US authorities said yesterday that removing the sanctions on Burma is cur- rently out of question as that would reward the regime for doing nothing.
1244.Description: Reject requests, refuse, or decline to reduce or eliminate economic sanctions, boycotts, or embargoes.

201.Usage Notes: Note that this event form is different from expulsions of diplomats (161), international or non-governmental groups (166), and legal deportations (174). Mass expulsions coded here are typically carried out with the intention of clearing out a particular group of people out of a specific area.
201.Name: Engage in mass expulsion
201.Example: The Israeli army forced out on Wednesday more than 1,000 Palestinian refugees from their homes in a West Bank refugee camp during a 48-hour search for militants, residents said.
201.Description: Force large groups of people or populations out of some territory

200.Usage Notes: This residual category is not coded except when distinctions among codes 201-204 cannot be made.
200.Name: Use massive unconventional force, not specified below
200.Description: All uses of unconventional force that are meant to cause mass destruction, casualties, and suffering not otherwise specified.

144.Usage Notes: Use sub-categories if demands of protesters are known and codeable. Use this event form to code protest activities that seek to disrupt routine and normal proceedings by blocking roads, buildings, etc. When the blockade in question includes military forces, use 191 instead.
144.Name: Obstruct passage, block, not specified below
144.Example: Angry French paper workers blocked the Europe Bridge spanning the Rhine from France to West Germany for more than three hours by dumping sawdust on the roadway, French border police said.
144.Description: Protest by blocking entry and/or exit into building or area, not otherwise specified.

145.Usage Notes: Use sub-categories if demands of protesters are known and codeable. Use this event form to code demonstrations and protests that turn violent. When the use of force to cause casualties is the primary purpose, use categories 18, 19, or 20 instead.
145.Name: Protest violently, riot, not specified below
145.Example: Palestinian prisoners rioted Monday at this jail in northern Israel, setting fire to their mattresses and smashing furniture, police sources said.
145.Description: Protest forcefully, in a potentially destructive manner, not further specified.

142.Usage Notes: Use sub-categories if demands of protesters are known and codeable. The target for this event form is the party against which the hunger strikers protest.
142.Name: Conduct hunger strike, not specified below
142.Example: Up to 1,000 ethnic Turks began a hunger strike on Monday to protest against Sweden’s decision to send them back to Bulgaria, where they say they face imprisonment, homelessness and persecution.
142.Description: Protest by refusing to eat until certain demands are met, not further speci- fied.

143.Usage Notes: Use sub-categories if demands of protesters are known and codeable. The target for this event form is the party against which the hunger strikers protest. This event form does not refer to military strikes, which are coded under category 19 instead.
143.Name: Conduct strike or boycott, not specified below
143.Example: Palestinians of the Israeli-occupied West Bank shunned work on Monday to protest at settlement of Soviet Jewish immigrants on Arab land.
143.Description: Protest by refusing to work or cooperate until certain demands are met, not specified further.

140.Usage Notes: This residual category is not coded except when distinctions among codes 141-145 cannot be made. Note that any form of civilian individual or collective action that is undertaken as a symbol of support—rather than protest— for the target actor should be coded elsewhere (potentially under category 05).
140.Name: Engage in political dissent, not specified below.
140.Example: The Homeland Union (Conservatives) began collecting signatures in part of a drive to convince the Lithuanian Parliament to amend the constitution so that same-sex marriages are banned.
140.Description: All civilian demonstrations and other collective actions carried out as protests against the target actor not otherwise specified

141.Usage Notes: Use sub-categories if demands of protesters are known and codeable. The target for this event form is the party that the protest is directed against; the location of a demonstration sometimes represents the identity of the target.
141.Name: Demonstrate or rally, not specified below
141.Example: Up to 100 ethnic Albanians demonstrated on Tuesday in the Yugoslav province of Kosovo, where 24 people were killed in nationalist riots last March, Belgrade radio said.
141.Description: Dissent collectively, publicly show negative feelings or opinions; rally, gather to protest a policy, action, or actor(s).

083.Usage Notes: Note that this event type is different from ‘Express intent to institute political reform’ (034) as it involves the actual event of change—not just its promise. Just like military forms of yield, these could be voluntary concessions or involuntary surrenders.
083.Name: Accede to requests or demands for political reform, not specified below
083.Example: The Rwandan government on Thursday accepted demands from Hutu rebels that it initiate political reforms
083.Description: Yield by instituting requested political changes.

082.Usage Notes: Use this code for concessions by opposition groups in form of ending or putting on hold demonstrations, protests, rallies, etc.
082.Name: Ease political dissent
082.Example: The Nigerian Union of Teachers (NUT), the umbrella union for primary school teachers, announced Thursday that it has called off a four-day strike after deliberations with the Nigerian government.
082.Description: Cancel, suspend, or postpone any (non-war) activity that constitutes political dissent.

081.Usage Notes: This event category contains sub-forms for more detailed coding whenever possible.
081.Name: Ease administrative sanctions, not specified below
081.Example: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir, following the partial peace deal, has taken several tentative steps to enhance political freedoms and promote an image of openness and tolerance in Sudan.
081.Description: Relax or remove all administrative non-force sanctions and penalties, not otherwise specified.

080.Usage Notes: This residual category is not coded except when distinctions among codes 081-087 cannot be made. Not that all of the event forms under this category refer to reported yieldings and tot to future commitments, agreements, or promises.
080.Name: Yield, not specified below
080.Example: Uganda said on Sunday it had paid compensation to 67 elderly British nationals, most of the Asians, for assets they lost when former dictator Idi Amin expelled them 18 years ago.
080.Description: All yieldings, concessions not otherwise specified

087.Usage Notes: Use sub-categories for more detailed coding whenever possible. Note that only real manifestations of de-escalation are coded here, expressions of intent to de-escalate are not.
087.Name: De-escalate military engagement, not specified below
087.Description: Concede militarily, stop fighting, or take measures to ease military conflict or tension not further specified.

086.Usage Notes: Use the following sub-categories whenever possible. The types of international involvement covered in this category require physical access to territories under the source’s control. Note that accepting international involvement in the form of mediation is coded under 04. The target should be the international actor whose involvement is allowed or received
086.Name: Allow international involvement, not specified below
086.Example: Kyrgyz Prime Minister Nikolai Tanaev received a mission of observers from the OSCE, informing them in detail on the economic situation of the country.
086.Description: Allow entry of or intervention by international actors not further specified.

085.Usage Notes: Use this event form to code state activities that imply easing of limitations to normal economic relations.
085.Name: Ease economic sanction, boycott, or embargo
085.Example: Germany on Wednesday lifted sanctions against gold from South Africa in recognition of the country’s moves to abolish apartheid, a government spokesman said.
085.Description: Lift, relax, or lessen economic sanctions, boycott, embargoes, or penalties.

084.Usage Notes: This category contains sub-forms for more detailed coding whenever possible.
084.Name: Return, release, not specified below
084.Example: According to a zoo spokesperson Malaysian authorities have initiated the process of returning the four baby gorillas to Nigeria, amid speculations they were illegally captured in the wild.
084.Description: All acts of releasing or returning not otherwise specified.

1214.Usage Notes: Use this code when the source actor refuses to investigate or share information.
1214.Name: Reject intelligence cooperation
1214.Example: The UN on Tuesday imposed a de facto information blackout on the withdrawal, collection and monitoring of heavy weapons around Sarajevo.
1214.Description: Refuse to engage in or expand cooperation in intelligence or information sharing.

106.Usage Notes: This event form can be initiated by either the adversaries or other third parties.
106.Name: Demand meeting, negotiation
106.Example: Yugoslavia on Tuesday demanded a meeting of the U.N. Security Council to discuss Croatia’s military advance into the Serb-held Krajina region, describing it as “a serious challenge to the world community.”
106.Description: Require, order party(ies) to meet, negotiate.

1241.Name: Refuse to ease administrative sanctions
1241.Example: Despite warnings of starvation by humanitarian agencies, the Israeli govern- ment is refusing to lift the curfew on Palestinians living in the West Bank and Gaza.
1241.Description: Reject requests, refuse or decline to ease administrative sanctions, such as censorship, curfew, state of emergency, and martial law.

154.Usage Notes: The party against whom the military move is directed is the target actor
154.Name: Mobilize or increase armed forces
154.Example: Israel has strengthened its forces in Lebanon following the discovery of Soviet-made Katyusha rockets in the area last week, military sources said today.
154.Description: Increase the number of military personnel and/or weapons.

125.Usage Notes: Note that specific refusals to accept involvement of mediators or refusals to meet with mediators are coded as 126 instead.
125.Name: Reject proposal to meet, discuss, negotiate
125.Example: Israeli President Moshe Katsav has refused to meet Jordan’s visiting King Abdullah II in Tel Aviv, saying he would only welcome him in Jerusalem, his office said Tuesday.
125.Description: Refuse to meet, discuss, or negotiate.

1043.Usage Notes: This event form refers to verbal and non-threatening appeals. Demands that take the form of demonstrations, protests, etc. are coded under category 14 instead. If it is clear from the lead that by demanding certain rights the source is in fact appealing to the target to yield or concede, the event might be better coded under 105. Demands for provision of compensation for previously violated rights, for instance, are coded as 105.
1043.Name: Demand rights
1043.Example: The main Hutu rebel group, Forces for Defence of Democracy (FDD), insisted on its demands that Burundi’s government grant the Hutu majority more rights.
1043.Description: Require, demand provision or expansion of social, political, or other rights.

1042.Usage Notes: This event form refers to verbal and non-threatening appeals. Demands that take the form of demonstrations, protests, etc. are coded under category 14 instead. Just like the source actor, the policy in question can also be domestic or international in nature. If it is clear from the lead that by demanding certain policy changes the source is in fact appealing to the target to yield or concede, the event might be better coded under 105 (e.g. demands for military withdrawal should be coded as 1056).
1042.Name: Demand policy change
1042.Example: Opposition groups in Zimbabwe are demanding that President Mugabe abandon his controversial policy of land confiscations.
1042.Description: Require, demand change in any particular policy.

1041.Usage Notes: This event form refers to verbal and non-threatening appeals. Demands that take the form of demonstrations, protests, etc. are coded under category 14 instead. Note that even though demands for the target to resign or relinquish power are forms of yielding, they are still coded here. Also code demands for elections here (unless they are first-time elections and hence constitute major institutional change).
1041.Name: Demand leadership change
1041.Example: Sunnis have demanded that control of the Interior Ministry be taken away from Shiite religious parties in the next government.
1041.Description: Require, demand change in leadership or power

0841.Usage Notes: Formal pardons, amnesties, commutations, and exchanges of prisoners should all be coded here.
0841.Name: Return, release persons
0841.Example: Polish police today released the correspondent of the American news agency United Press International, who was detained for 23 hours and questioned in connection with an inquiry into alleged illegal activities.
0841.Description: Release people, including prisoners and hostages, from detention or arrest

195.Usage Notes: Use this event form to code bombings that involve the use of military aircrafts. When both aerial and other small types of weapons are used, this code takes precedence.
195.Name: Employ aerial weapons
195.Example: Soviet aircraft including helicopter gunships killed 46 Afghan civilians in an attack on a village in the western province of Heart.

0842.Usage Notes: When confiscated property or other rights are not returned but compensation is provided instead, those incidents should be coded as 080.
0842.Name: Return, release property
0842.Example: French maritime authorities today release an impounded ship operated by the Greenpeace ecology movement, port officials said.
0842.Description: Return or release previously controlled, confiscated property, including land

1382.Usage Notes: This event form is typically a verbal act and is distinct from 192, which refers to military occupations that have been or are being carried out
1382.Name: Threaten occupation
1382.Example: Ethnic Albanians have sworn to fight until they gain control of villages near Macedonia’s border with Kosovo, Macedonian officials said Wednesday.
1382.Description: Threaten to occupy, seize control of the whole or part of a territory

1431.Usage Notes: Target should be the actor who is expected to relinquish power. Strikes or boycotts that demand new elections should also be coded here.
1431.Name: Conduct strike or boycott for leadership change
1431.Example: The fundamentalist Umma (Nation) party has said it will boycott Algeria’s first multi-party elections unless the president agrees to step down.
1431.Description: Refuse to work or cooperate until demands for leadership change are met.

172.Usage Notes: This event form category contains sub-forms for more detailed coding whenever possible.
172.Name: Impose administrative sanctions, not specified below
172.Description: Formal decrees, laws, or policies aimed at curbing the rights of civilians not otherwise specified.

107.Usage Notes: This event form is typically, although not exclusively, a verbal act. Note that the source for this event cannot be the adversaries themselves. When one or more parties to a conflict call for ending the conflict, that is taken to be an expression of intent on the part of that source actor and is thus coded as 037 instead.
107.Name: Demand settling of dispute
107.Example: Jack Straw said on Friday that the Sudanese government and the rebels in Darfur must reach an agreement that stops the conflict for good before developmental assistance to the region is released.
107.Description: Order parties to a conflict to reach a settlement, agreement, or resolution of conflict.

123.Usage Notes: If the reform in question clearly constitutes some form of concession or yield- ing by the source, such as the easing of existing administrative sanctions, a more appropriate code might be found under 124 (’Decline to yield’). Ac- tors requesting the demand or those (the country or the people) that will be affected by the rejection should be coded as target depending on availability of information in the lead.
123.Name: Reject request or demand for political reform, not specified below
123.Example: The US on Thursday rejected calls by Kofi Annan, UN secretary-general, to adopt far-reaching United Nations reforms as a comprehensive package.
123.Description: Refuse to institute political change not otherwise specified.

0314.Usage Notes: This event form refers to agreements, promises, commitments, or other indications of intent to develop or expand intelligence cooperation by providing or exchanging intelligence or information.
0314.Name: Express intent to cooperate on intelligence
0314.Example: Israel and the Palestinians reached a consensus to exchange information on water resources on the second day of a multilateral conference on water problems in the Middle East here Thursday, the meeting’s co-chairman said.
0314.Description: Offer, promise, agree to, or otherwise indicate willingness or commitment to engage in or expand intelligence sharing.

124.Usage Notes: This category contains sub-forms for more detailed coding whenever possible.
124.Name: Refuse to yield, not specified below
124.Description: Reject requests, refuse, or decline to yield not otherwise specified.

0311.Usage Notes: This event form refers to agreements, promises, commitments, or other indications of intent to develop or expand trade and other forms of economic exchange. Offers, promises, or commitments by one actor to provide economic aid to another should be coded as 0331 instead.
0311.Name: Express intent to cooperate economically
0311.Example: The United States and Jordan have agreed upon a new free-trade pact between the two countries, the White House announced Tuesday.
0311.Description: Offer, promise, agree to, or otherwise indicate willingness or commitment to engage in or expand economic ties.

0312.Usage Notes: This event form refers to agreements, promises, commitments, or other indications of intent to develop or expand military relations by engaging in such acts as joint military maneuvers or exercises. Offers, promises, or commitments by one actor to provide military aid to another should be coded as 0332 instead.
0312.Name: Express intent to cooperate militarily
0312.Example: Jordan and Britain have agreed to undertake joint military exercises this month, a Jordanian official confirmed.
0312.Description: Offer, promise, agree to, or otherwise indicate willingness or commitment to engage in or expand military ties

0313.Usage Notes: This event form refers to agreements, promises, commitments, or other indications of intent to develop or expand judicial cooperation by engaging in such acts as extraditions.
0313.Name: Express intent to cooperate on judicial matters
0313.Example: Libya has offered to hand over to an Arab country two of its nationals suspected by the West of blowing up a Pan Am plane in 1988, a state-owned Egyptian newspaper said.
0313.Description: Offer, promise, agree to, or otherwise indicate willingness or commitment to engage in or expand judicial cooperation.
